transcript.text: Trademarks are one way we protect our Intellectual Property. Click on each heading to find out more.

contentText.text: We use trademarks to protect the value of our brand, products, and services.

instructionText.text: Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

popText.text: A trademark is a recognizable sign, design or expression that identifies products or services of a particular source, as compared to those of others.
Trademarks used to identify services are usually called service marks.

A trademark can be owned by:
  • an individual
  • a corporation
  • another legal entity

revealCallOut.img: Registered Trademark Symbol superimposed above a businessman using a tablet computer

popText.text: A trademark can be placed on a package, a label or on the product itself, or even show up when software is launched.
A trademark can be placed on a company building to ensure corporate identity.
The trademark owner can establish property rights through actual use in the marketplace or by registering the mark with the trademarks office.
Once a trademark is registered, no other entity may use it unless the trademark owner licenses the trademark to others, allowing them to use the same trademark.

revealCallOut.buttonText: What happens if the trademark is used by another party without a license?

popText.text: The owner of the trademark may pursue legal action against that party for trademark infringement.

revealCallOut.buttonText: What do some of the symbols you might see next to a trademark mean?

popText.text:
• TM is the symbol for an unregistered trademark
  • SM is the symbol for an unregistered service mark, used to promote or brand services
  • ® is the symbol for a trademark that is registered
